head.ce:title: Construction of ultra-thin 2D CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx photo-catalyst with rapid electron and hole separation for efficient bisphenol A degradation

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Br and ultra-fine dispersed RhOx nanoparticles were decorated on the ultrathin 2D g-C3N4 to induce high separation efficiency of photo-induced electrons and holes, resulting in high performance of degradation 10 ppm BPA within 9 min under visible light condition.

g-C3N4 (CN), which shows enormous potential for photocatalysis, has long been studied, but still exhibits an unsatisfactory degradation rate. Herein, dual cocatalysts, Br and ultrafine RhOx nanoparticles, were constructed on ultrathin CN for synergetic photocatalysis. Ultrathin CN increased the exciton separation efficiency, while cocatalysts Br and RhOx can accelerated electron and hole transfer simultaneously, maximizing the photocatalytic degradation performance of CN. This CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx degraded 10 ppm bisphenol A (BPA) in 9 min, which represents the fastest degradation rate reported to date. This excellent performance was also demonstrated by a larger photocurrent response, higher separation efficiency, and faster transfer rate for electron–hole pairs than CN. This work obtained an enhanced electron–hole separation efficiency and migration rate by combing ultrathin CN with dual-channel cocatalysts, leading to the best photocatalytic degradation performance reported for CN.

ce:section.ce:para: Solar energy can drive semiconductor materials to generate active free radicals for water pollutant treatment, with photocatalysis considered a potentially ideal method for this process owing to its low-cost, environmental friendliness, and energy-saving [1]. The application of photocatalysis is hindered by the inefficient separation of photo-induced electron–hole pairs, which leads to low catalytic efficiency. Two-dimensional (2D) g-C3N4 (CN) has tremendous attention in photocatalysis owing to its promising properties, such as low cost, ease of fabrication, and robust chemical stability. However, CN exhibits inefficient light-harvesting and a low separation efficiency of electron–hole pairs, which are unfavorable for photocatalytic applications [2]. In the last few years, many studies have attempted to improve the photocatalyst performance of CN, with approaches including doping [3], surface active-site regulation [4], and constructing surface heterojunctions [5]. However, such modified photocatalyst systems still show unsatisfactory degradation efficiency for bisphenol A (BPA), a typical endocrine disruptor that can affect reproductive behavior and physical development. The photocatalytic degradation performance of CN can be improved from two aspects, one is to promote the efficiency of photoinduced h+–e– pairs separation [6,7], and the other is to introduce enough migration sites for electron–hole pairs to realize rapid transfer of electrons and holes [8,9], inhibiting their recombination. For CN, a smaller thickness results in better electron–hole separation efficiency. This can be attributed to the distance between electrons and holes migrating to the solid–liquid reaction interface being reduced on ultrathin CN, which suppresses charge recombination in bulk CN, realizing effective electron–hole separation [10]. Furthermore, cocatalysts can largely accelerate the transfer of electron–hole pairs to surface active sites and inhibit carrier recombination [11,12]. The introduction of a single cocatalyst improves the photocatalytic degradation ability of the photocatalytic redox process, which provides only a single channel for the migration of electrons or holes [13]. Therefore, using supported dual cocatalysts to improve the simultaneous transfer of electrons and holes is a promising method for increasing photocatalytic efficiency.

Bromine is an electron-transfer mediator whose lone-pair electrons readily delocalize on the π-conjugate structure of CN, leading to a narrower bandgap and lower work function for CN, which ultimately promotes electron migration [14]. Liu reported that Br substitution on perylenetetracarboxylic diimide (PTCDI) improved visible-light utilization and reduced interface electron-transfer resistance, facilitating enhanced photocatalytic activity and stability [15]. Yu investigated halogen-doped g-C3N4 photocatalyst using first principles, with density of states (DOS) and molecular orbital calculation results showing that the g-C3N4 after the modification of halogen had narrow band gap, wide light absorption range, and small work functions, indictaing the good photocatalytic performance of halogen-doped g-C3N4 from a theoretical perspective [16]. Rhodium oxide (RhOx) has been widely used in various applications, including photocatalysis and electrocatalysis [17–19]. Xu deposited cocatalyst RhOx on ZnTiO3-xNy hollow nanospheres to promote the oxygen evolution half-reaction, with RhOx acting as a hole-transfer mediator, as proven by simulation of the photocarrier distribution [20]. Chen reported that Ti/IrO2-RhOx-Ta2O5 containing the redox pair of Rh3+ and Rh4+ contributed to improved activity and stability compared with Ti/IrO2-Ta2O5 [19,21,22]. Furthermore, the numerous N active sites in CN can coordinate with Rh, which greatly inhibits the RhOx aggregation [23], and achieves ultrafine and uniformly dispersed RhOx nanoparticles on CN, affording more exposed catalytic active sites and higher catalytic activity [24,25].

In this study, a composite catalyst, CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx, was prepared by introducing dual-channel cocatalysts, Br and RhOx nanoparticles, onto ultrathin CN for BPA degradation. After screening of conditions, CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx degraded 10 ppm BPA in 9 min with visible light, which is the fastest BPA degradation rate reported under these conditions, attributing to the remarkable electron–hole pairs separation and transport properties. Furthermore, fluorescence (FL), time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) spectra, and transient photo-current were used to explain the excellent BPA degradation ability of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx. The specific mechanism of cocatalysts Br and RhOx in the photocatalytic degradation process was clarified in detail using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), electron spin resonance (ESR), cyclic voltammetry (CV) and Mott–Schottky plots. Considering improvements in the efficient separation and migration of photo-induced excitons, the photocatalytic performance of the semiconductors was greatly improved, providing a reference for future photocatalyst design.

Urea, ammonium bromide, and trisodium hexachlororhodate were bought from Aladdin Reagent. p-Benzoquinone, triethanolamine, bisphenol A, isopropyl alcohol, ethanol, and methanol were purchased from Macklin.

2D CN nanosheets were prepared with the thermal polymerization. Urea (10 g) was heated to 550 °C (5 °C min–1) for 2 h in air. After ultrasound treatment for 10 h, the prepared pale-yellow samples were collected for further use.

The preparation method of Br-modified CN was similar to that of CN, but with different amounts of ammonium bromide added to urea by grinding before subsequent thermal polymerization. Br-modified CN was denoted as CN-Brx, x representing the mass of ammonium bromide (x = 0.02 – 0.48 g).

CN-Br0.12 nanosheets were dispersed in aqueous Na3RhCl6 solution. 2 mL NH3·H2O was then injected and stirred for 2 h. The mixture was heated to dryness at 100 °C for subsequent calcination at 250 °C. The final samples were denoted as CN-Br0.12/X%RhOx, where X% represents the mass percentage of RhOx relative to CN-Br0.12 (X% = 0.5 %, 1%, 2%, and 4%).

The morphology and element mapping images of samples were measured with scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi SU8230) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F20 and Titan Cubed Themis G2 300). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, X'Pert-Pro MPD) patterns were recorded from 10 to 80 °. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using an ESCALAB 250 XI system with Al-Kα radiation. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy (VERTEX 70 + HYPERION 2000) and solid-state NMR spectroscopy (AVANCEIII/WB-400) were used to analyze the chemical structure of samples. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–vis, DRS Shimadzu UV–3600) was used to explore the optical properties. Free radicals were measured by the electron spin resonance (ESR, JES-X320) with 5,5′-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) and (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-yl)oxyl (TEMPO). Height spectra of CN were obtained by atomic force microscopy (AFM, Multimode). Fluorescence (PL) emission spectra were gotten using a FLS920 spectrophotometer with an excitation wavelength at 380 nm. The intermediate products were detected by HPLC (Waters 2695) and liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC–MS; Waters ZQ2000). The total organic carbon (TOC) concentration was recorded using a TOC analyzer (Multi N/C 2100, Analytic Jena). Electrochemical measurements were conducted on a CHI-660E electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument, Shanghai).

The photocatalytic performance of CN, CN-Brx, and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx samples was evaluated in the degradation of BPA. Photocatalyst (10 mg) was completely dispersed in 10-ppm BPA solution (15 mL, pH = 7). Before irradiation, reaction mixture was in the dark for 30 min to remove the effect of physical absorption from evaluation of the photocatalytic performance. During the degradation process, 0.7 mL aliquots of the reaction system were extracted at fixed time intervals after irradiation by a 250 W Xenon lamp (XD-300−250 W, Perfect Light) with a cutting filter (λ>420 nm). The BPA concentration was determined by HPLC of the tested samples after filtration through a filter tip.

As shown in Figs. 1 (a) and S1, the 2D ultrathin graphene-like morphologies of the CN, CN-Br0.12, and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx were observed by SEM and TEM, with the sample edges observed to be rolled up due to surface tension. The ultrathin CN nanosheets had a thickness of about 3–4 nm according to AFM topological height analysis, as shown in Fig. 1(b)–(d). Cocatalyst RhOx nanoparticles were distributed on CN nanosheets with an average size about 2 nm, as clearly shown in Fig. 1(e), and by numerous bright spots by scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) (Fig. S2). From the HR-TEM images (Fig. 1(f)–(i)), distinct lattice fringes with an interplanar spacings of 0.259, 0.252, and 0.169 nm, corresponding to the (112) and (021) crystal planes of Rh2O3, and (211) crystal plane of RhO2, indicated the formation of RhOx nanoparticles [26,27]. The corresponding elemental mapping images (Fig. 1(j)) of C, N, Br, Rh, and O further showed that the ultrathin 2D CN nanosheets successfully modified with Br and RhOx.

Furthermore, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were analyzed (Fig. S3). All samples exhibited a typical IV isotherm featuring an obvious H3-type hysteresis loop with high adsorption at P/P0 approaching 1.0, which supported the existence of large mesopores and macropores inside the multicomponent catalyst composites [28,29]. The specific surface area of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx was 51.96 m2 g−1, and the average pore size was about 33.68 nm, as measured using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The corresponding textural parameters of CN, CN-Br0.12, and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx samples are shown in Table S1. Compared with CN-Br0.12, CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx exhibited a relatively decreased specific surface area. RhOx dominated some of the pores of CN-Br0.12 after introduction, resulting in a decrease in the specific surface area of CN-Br0.12.

XRD, solid-state 13C NMR, and FT-IR were conducted to analyze the chemical composition, structure, and crystal form of the as-prepared CN, CN-Brx, and CN-Br0.12/X%RhOx samples. These samples all showed similar XRD patterns (Fig. 2 (a)), confirming successful fabrication of the CN phase. Two distinct XRD broad peaks were observed at 13.2 ° and 27.7 ° for all samples, attributed to the (100) and (002) planes [30]. The (100) plane corresponded to the repeating units of triazine heterocycles, while that at 27.7 ° was assigned to graphitic layer stacking, which is similar to that reported for ultrathin graphene [31]. However, RhOx showed no distinct peaks in XRD patterns probably due to its small size and the deposition of RhOx cocatalyst on CN had no obvious influences on its crystal phase structure and crystallinity [32]. To further investigate the chemical structures of the samples, 13C NMR and FT-IR spectra of the samples were recorded. Fig. 2(b) shows the 13C NMR spectra of CN, CN-Br0.12, and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx, exhibiting two distinct peaks at δ = 165.26 and 156.79 ppm. The first peak was assigned to sp2-hybridized C in NCN moieties, while the second peak was attributed to sp3-hybridized C atoms in melem (CN3) [19,33]. These signals confirmed the existence of heptazine units and poly(tri-s-triazine) structures in CN, CN-Br0.12, and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx. The FT-IR spectra showed that all samples exhibited similar vibration modes (Fig. 2(c) and (d)), suggesting that small amounts of the Br and RhOx cocatalysts on CN nanosheets did not change the chemical structure of CN [34]. The absorption peak of typical breathing and stretching vibration modes of aromatic CN heterocycles and heptazine units were located at 1200−1600 cm−1 and 810 cm−1, respectively [35,36]. The above results indicated that CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx maintained the properties of CN after the modification of Br and RhOx thus promised the potential photocatalytic applications.

XPS tests were performed, to examine the chemical composition, states and the interaction between Br, RhOx and CN. C 1s XPS analysis of CN (Fig. 3 (a)) showed peaks located at 284.80 (calibration peak) and 288.23 eV, attributed to CC and the sp2-hybridized carbon atoms in the form of NCN [37]. Ignoring the calibration peak, the NCN peaks of CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.48 were positively shifted relative to that of CN, to 288.28 and 288.38 eV, respectively. Furthermore, the N 1s spectrum of CN in Fig. 3(b) could be deconvoluted into four peaks at 398.33, 400.11, 401.04, and 404.92 eV, which were assigned to CNC, (C) 3N, NH , and π-excitation signals [38]. With an increasing doping amount of Br, the four N peaks shifted in the negative direction to different degrees, with CN-Br0.48 showing the largest negative shift of 0.18 eV for the CNC peak. Modification with Br caused the C and N signals of CN to shift positively and negatively, implying changes in the electron cloud density of CN after Br modification. Increased electron cloud density was observed on N, with markedly decreased electron cloud density on C, confirming strong chemical and electronic coupling interactions between Br and CN [30,39–42]. A single obvious Br 3d peak was observed at 67.41 eV for CN-Br0.48 (Fig. 3(c)), which was assigned to Br– [43]. Br was present in the internal structure of CN, as shown by the Br peak intensity remaining consistent with an increasing etching depth (Fig. S4) [39]. Furthermore, RhOx had a strong interaction with CN-Br0.12. The introduction of RhOx had little effect on the C 1s signal of CN-Br0.12 (Fig. 3(d)). However, the N 1s peak was shifted to a higher energy when RhOx was loaded onto CN-Br0.12 (Fig. 3(e)) [44], indicating that the electron density of the N atoms was lower in the presence of RhOx. This decrease in the electron density of N atoms, which is a typical feature of complex formation [45], can be attributed to the formation of RhN coordination bonds [46–48]. This coordination inhibited the growth of RhOx nanoparticles, which had a size of about 2 nm, as observed by TEM. As shown in Fig. 3(f), the Rh (3d3/2 and 3d5/2) XPS spectra of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx were well divided into four peaks positioned at 308.72, 313.23, 309.49, and 314.21 eV, respectively. The peak at 308.72 eV corresponded to the characteristic peaks of Rh3+, while that at 309.49 eV was attributed to Rh4+, illustrating mixed chemical states in the Rh species [26,27]. Electro-deficient Rhx+ species might be caused by coordination between Rh and CN [49].

The photocatalytic activity of the as-prepared samples was evaluated in the photocatalytic degradation of BPA under visible-light irradiation. Under irradiation by a 250 W Xenon (Xe) lamp with a 420 nm cut-off filter, pure CN showed relatively poor photocatalytic activity for the photodegradation of 10 ppm BPA, with a degradation rate of only 56.4 % within 75 min. This was attributed to the recombination of photo-induced h+ and e–. The degradation rates of CN-Brx were strongly dependent on the amount of NH4Br added. Although little amounts of NH4Br (0.02 g) enhanced the photocatalytic activity, the degradation rate was higher than that of pure CN. CN-Br0.12 degraded 66.5 % of BPA within 75 min under the same conditions, showing the highest degradation rate among the CN-Brx samples. When the amount of NH4Br was increased to 0.32 g, the conjugate structure of CN was slightly damaged, resulting in a significant decline in the degradation rate (Fig. 4 (a)). Furthermore, after adding RhOx nanoparticles, the degradation performance of CN/X%RhOx was greatly improved (Fig. 4(b)). When the RhOx content was increased to 2%, BPA was 92.9 % degraded within only 30 min. When the RhOx content was further increased, the RhOx particle size became larger and aggregation started to occur, which led to weakened degradation activity (Fig. S5). Notably, all CN-Br0.12/X%RhOx nanocomposites exhibited higher photocatalytic performance than CN-Brx and CN-X%RhOx nanocomposites (Fig. 4(c)). Within 10 min, the degradation rates of CN-Br0.12/0.5 %RhOx, CN-Br0.12/1%RhOx, CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx, and CN-Br0.12/4%RhOx were 80.06 %, 83.54 %, 100 %, and 82.86 %, respectively. CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx degraded 10 ppm BPA in 9 min, which is the fastest degradation rate reported for CN-based catalysts to date (Table S2). As shown in Fig. S6, CN, CN-Br0.12, and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx exhibited continuously increasing total organic carbon (TOC) removal efficiencies with continuous irradiation, with the TOC removal reaching 47.7 % after continuous irradiation for 1 h. The results suggested that as-prepared CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx not only degraded, but also mineralized, the organic pollutant. To explore its application scope for organic pollutant degradation, the CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx composite photocatalyst was applied to the degradation of other bisphenol analogues (phenol, 2,4-dichlorophenol, and methylparaben) and different types of organic pollutant (tetracycline and rhodamine B). CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx completely degraded 10 ppm rhodamine B and tetracycline within 6 and 9 min, respectively. Furthermore, the degradation rates for phenol, 2,4-dichlorophenol, and methylparaben were 44.3 %, 73.1 % and 53.1 % within 12 min (Fig. S7). These results show that CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx composite photocatalysts are not selective and can effectively degrade different types of organic pollutant.

In addition to catalytic performance, the stability of the photocatalyst was also studied carefully. First, the effect of pH on catalytic activity was investigated. There is no obvious decline in BPA removal was found with pH from 3 to 9, indicating excellent photocatalytic activity over a wide pH environment (Fig. S8). When the pH increased to 11, the photocatalytic activity had a slight decline. The good photocatalytic degradation performance was due to the coordination of Rh with N in CN [50]. The photocatalytic cycling performance of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx for BPA removal was then studied by conducting six successive photocatalytic reactions under the same conditions (Fig. 4(d)). The degradation efficiency of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx was still higher than 95.2 % after four uses, decreasing to 92.5 % on the fifth use and 89.1 % on the sixth use. After successive photodegradation reaction, the photocatalytic performance of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx for BPA removal did not decrease significantly, indicating that CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx had good cycling performance. Finally, to confirm the stability of the CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx after photodegradation, the used CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx sample was further measured by XPS, UV–vis, FT-IR, and XRD. The relative contents of the two C 1s peaks in the XPS spectra had slightly changed after reaction (Fig. S9(a)), which might be due to photocorrosion [51]. No obvious change in the chemical state of N (Fig. S9(b)) was observed for CN. Figure S9(c) shows the XPS spectra of Rh 3d in the CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx sample before and after the reaction. The relative contents of Rh3+ and Rh4+ clearly changed, corroborating the mechanism proposed below, in which holes hop between Rh3+ and Rh4+ at O-sites in the intense redox environment [8,52]. Furthermore, the bandgap (Fig. S9(d)), chemical structure (Fig. S9(e)), and crystallinity (Fig. S9(f)) of the material showed no obvious change. The above results demonstrated the high stability of the efficient photocatalyst, indicating the potential practical applications of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx to organic pollutant degradation in water.

CN-Br0.12/X%RhOx has enhanced photocatalytic activity attributed to rapid charge separation with the addition of the dual cocatalysts, which improved the photocatalytic activity for BPA removal. The following experiments were used to confirm this conjecture. First, the optical properties were carefully measured by UV–vis DRS (Fig. 5 (a) and (b)). The absorption band of all samples began from 440 nm, which was in accordance with traditional CN semiconductors [53]. Notably, when the amount of ammonium bromide was increased from 0.02 to 0.48 g, the absorption range of CN-Brx was slightly broadened. Correspondingly, the sample color changed from light yellow to dark yellow. After introducing RhOx nanoparticles on CN-Br0.12, due to the low doping amount of RhOx nanoparticles, the optical absorption properties showed almost no change at all. The electron–hole separation efficiency of the photocatalysts was then probed by PL analysis (Fig. 5(c)). All showed similar peaks centered at about 480 nm after excited by 380 nm UV light. However, the PL emission intensity was reduced after CN was modified with Br and RhOx, which proved weakened electron–hole recombination [14,54]. To gain further evidence regarding the charge separation rates of bare CN, CN-Br0.12, and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx, TRPL was conducted (Fig. 5(d) and Table S3). The lifetime of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx was shown to be 8.315 ns, which was slower than those of CN (10.420 ns) and CN-Br0.12 (10.369 ns), indicating a faster electron–hole pair separation rate, which was due to the presence of an electron and hole migration highway, namely, cocatalysts Br and RhOx [2].

Photoelectrochemical measurements, including EIS and transient photocurrent, were measured to further study the catalyst samples. Three samples all showed similar semicircular Nyquist plots at high frequencies (Fig. 5(e)). The Nyquist cycle of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx had a much smaller than those of CN and CN-Br0.12, implying that it had the smallest charge transfer resistance. The fitted charge transfer resistance (Rct) values based on the equivalent circuit are summarized in Table S4. The Rct values of CN (4032 Ω), CN-Br0.12 (3570 Ω), and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx (838 Ω) suggested that CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx and CN-Br0.12 possessed better electron transfer quantities compared with pure CN [55,56]. Furthermore, the transient photocurrent responses of various CN materials are shown in Fig. 5(f). All tested samples exhibited obvious transient photocurrent responses, the photocurrent intensity following the order of CN < CN-Br0.12 < CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx. These results indicated that CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx with dual cocatalysts exhibited remarkably high electron–hole separation efficiency compared with CN-Br0.12 and CN. These results confirmed that introducing Br and RhOx increased the conductivity of CN, improved the separation efficiency and transfer rate of photogenerated h+–e– pairs, and increased the density of photogenerated carriers, which clearly explained the excellent photocatalytic BPA degradation achieved by CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx.
In order to explore the transfer property of photoinduced charges, it was necessary to clarify the special role of Br and RhOx on CN nanosheets in the photodegradation process.

The ability of Br to accept electrons from CN was confirmed follows. First, the electronic property of CN-Br0−0.48 was measured by room temperature ESR. All samples exhibited a single Lorentzian signal with a g value of 2.003 in the dark (Fig. 6 (a)), originating from lone electrons on π-conjugated CN [57]. As the initial amount of ammonium bromide increased, more unpaired electrons were delocalized to the π-conjugated CN aromatic ring, as evidenced by the enhanced ESR intensity. This confirmed that Br modification promoted electron mobility in the π-conjugated system of CN, potentially due to the delocalization of the valance electron of Br to the CN conjugation system and thus widen the band distribution to improve charge migration [58,59]. Furthermore, VB–XPS spectrum was performed to measure CN, CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx valence band (VB), and valence band positions (EVB) were gotten using linear extrapolation. The valence band positions of CN, CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx were appropriate, at 1.44, 1.71 and 1.51 eV (Fig. 6(b)) and Fig. S10). The positive shift of the VB after Br modification confirmed delocalization of the valance electrons to CN which increased the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy level of CN and improved charge migration [39,60,61]. Furthermore, Br has electron-acceptor characteristics owing to its strong electronegativity and conductivity [62], as confirmed by EIS. Finally, Fig. S11 shows that the measured flat-band potentials (VFB) of CN and CN-Br0.12 were –0.76 and –0.69 eV with reference to a Ag/AgCl electrode, which corresponded to –0.56 and –0.49 eV versus the normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) [63]. The flat band was considered to be the Fermi level (EF) [64,65]. The work function was calculated using the equation Φ = EVac − EF, where EVac represents the vacuum level potential. As the work function represented the minimum energy required for electrons to escape from the Fermi level to the vacuum level, the decreased work function of CN after modification with Br indicated that Br promoted the electron escape from CN, which might be intrinsically related to the strong electronegativity of Br [66]. In summary, doping with halogen atoms facilitated electron escape from the CN surface, which was consistent with the previous finding of enhanced surface charge transfer [39,62,66,67].

The hole migration mechanism was also investigated in detail. Mott–Schottky (MS) curves of CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx were measured under dark conditions. CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx exhibited a positive slope (Fig. 6(c)), indicating n-type semiconductors of the two samples. The flat-band potential (VFB) of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx shifted negatively by 235 mV after the deposition of RhOx. The smaller VFB of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx corresponded to its more negative onset potential [21]. In particular, the carrier densities of CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx were calculated to be 1.25 × 1022 and 6.69 × 1022 cm–3 [68]. The larger carrier densities showed the distinct hole-extraction capability of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx [68,69]. To further prove the hole migration mechanism, cyclic voltammetry was conducted for CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx in the dark. The CV curves (Fig. S12) showed that a pair of distinct redox peaks were detected in CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx, which were attributed to the redox couple of Rh3+/Rh4+, while no apparent redox couples were detected in CN-Br0.12 [22,50,70]. Owing to the presence of the variable valence states of Rh, holes were able to hop between different valence states to achieve hole migration [19,20].

To investigate the energy-band structure of the samples, the values of band gap (Eg) for CN, CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx are obtained by the Kubelka–Munk equation (Eq. a):

Where n is decided by the transition characteristic of the semiconductor. The calculated Eg of CN, CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx are approximately 2.72, 2.58 and 2.58 eV (Fig. S13). According to Eq. (b):

The conduction band (ECB) can be obtained by Eq. (b) with the values of EVB and Eg. The ECB of CN, CN-Br0.12 and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx are −1.28, −0.87 and −1.07 eV (Fig. 6(d)). In addition to the charge transfer property, the energy-band structure of the composite product is calculated, which are conducive to further exploring the mechanism of the composite catalyst below.

To explore the active species in the degradation process for BPA, some sacrificial agents were used to capture active species. Fig. 7 (a) shows the radicals trapping experiments of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx, with the addition of triethanolamine (TEA) to trap h+, benzoquinone (BQ) to trap superoxide radicals (O
2–), and isopropyl alcohol (IPA) to trap hydroxyl radicals (
OH), respectively [71]. The photocatalytic performance of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx showed an obvious activity decline after the adding of TEA or BQ, which showed that h+ and O
2– were active species involved in the removal of BPA. In particular, the degradation activity of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx was almost lost with the introduction of BQ, indicating that O
2– played a key role in BPA photodegradation. However, the photocatalytic activity of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx was almost unaffected by the addition of IPA, due to the redox potential of the hybrid samples being insufficient to produce
OH. The presence of O
2– radicals, O
H radicals, and h+ was further demonstrated by ESR analysis. As shown in Figs. 7(b), S14(a), and S14(b), there is no O
2– signals in the dark. Notably, the signals of O
2– began to appear and their signal intensity gradually increased, indicating that O
2– was indeed produced under irradiation in the CN, CN-Br, and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx systems. In contrast, the h+ signal of CN, CN-Br0.12, and CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx was strong in the dark (Figs. 7(c), S14(c), and S14(d)), and gradually decreased with extended irradiation time, verifying that h+ also contributed to improving the photodegradation activity. The O
H signals were not detected in the three samples (Fig. 7(d)), which was consistent with the capture experiment results. Based on the above analysis, the active species in the three photodegradation reaction samples were
O2– and h+ rather than O
H.

LC–MS was used to explore the generated intermediates (Fig. 8 , Fig. S15) during the photodegradation process. BPA degradation was proposed to occur via two pathways, radical attack on benzene rings or isopropyl moieties between two benzene rings. On the one hand, the benzene ring of BPA was ruptured by the attack of ·O2 −, which played a significant role in the ring-cleavage of aromatic compounds [72], forming organic acids product oxalic acid (B: m/z(-) = 90) and (2Z,7Z)-5,5-dimethyl-4,6-dioxonona-2,7-dienedioic acid (C: m/z(-) = 239). Bonds with isopropyl groups of C were broken, yielding (Z)-5-methyl-4-oxohexa-2,5-dienoic acid (D: m/z(-) = 139) and maleic acid (E: m/z(-) = 115) by h+, which possessed strong oxidizing properties. On the other hand, bonds with isopropyl groups were broken to give phenol (G: m/z(-) = 93) and 4-isopropylphenol (I: m/z(-) = 135). Hydroquinone (H: m/z(+) = 109) could be formed (in theoretical, but not detected) from oxidation of phenol by holes. The product 4-(prop-1-en-2-yl) phenol (J: m/z(-) = 133) was formed through dehydrogenation reaction from the fragment I. And 1-(4-hydroxyphenyl) ethan-1-one (K: m/z(-) = 135) was produced from product J through further oxidation. The carbonyl group of K was oxidized to the carboxyl group in product 4-hydroxybenzoic acid (L: m/z(-) = 137) [73]. After further oxidation, H was cracked to generate E. And E was further oxidized to form smaller organic acid B, which was finally completely mineralized into CO2 and H2O.

According to the above characterization analysis and literature reports, a mechanism was proposed for the CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx photodegradation of BPA, as shown in Fig. 9 . CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx generated e− and h+ at the photocatalyst with irradiation (Eq. 1). The generated electrons in the CB were easily accepted by Br. Electron migration from Br reduced molecular O2 to form O
2 −, which had a more negative reduction potential (−1.07 eV) compared with E(O2/O
2 −) [−0.33 eV vs. NHE] (Eq. 2). Furthermore, the holes in the VB tended to be consumed by Rh3+ to form Rh4+ (Eq. 3). Finally, the oxidized Rh4+ produced h+ to oxidize BPA, reforming Rh3+ (Eq. 4). Simultaneously, the produced h+ and O
2– directly decomposed BPA (Eq. 5). The detailed degradation processes were as follows:
(1) Cat. + hν → e– + h+
(2) e–(cat.) + O2 →
O2–
(3) Rh3+ + h+ → Rh4+
(4) Rh4+ → Rh3+ + h+
(5)
O2–, h+ + BPA → CO2 + H2O

A simple strategy to modify ultrathin 2D CN nanosheets with Br and RhOx nanoparticles is reported. The introduction of dual cocatalysts Br and RhOx separately improved the photogenerated h+–e– pairs separation efficiency and the photocatalytic performance of CN. Furthermore, the as-synthesized CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx catalyst achieved the highest photocatalytic degradation performance for CN, showing a large photocurrent response, high separation efficiency, and fast separation rate for electron–hole pairs. More importantly, CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx degraded 10 ppm BPA in 9 min, which was the fastest time reported to date. The synergetic mechanism of dual-channel cocatalysts Br and RhOx in the photocatalytic degradation process was confirmed by ESR, XPS, CV, and Mott–Schottky plots. In this process, the lone-pair electrons of Br are delocalized into CN, which is conducive to electron migration, while RhOx mainly acts as a medium for hole migration. The introduction of dual-channel cocatalysts greatly promoted the separation of electron-holes pairs, greatly improving the photocatalytic degradation rate of BPA. These results provide a foundation for the future application of CN-Br0.12/2%RhOx to pollutant degradation.
